comments.commentBody: Dr W, the accountants version is: A man worked at the same company for over 30 years. Every morning when he came to work he pulled a little key out of his vest pocket, open a drawer, peered inside, locked the drawer and started work. One morning he didn't show up for work. His boss went to his house and found that he was dead but that he had dressed for work. The boss reached into the vest pocket and pulled out the key. Back at the office, everyone stood around expectantly because -- finally -- the mystery would be solved. When the boss opened the drawer inside he found a single piece of paper that said, "Debits on the left, credits on the right." You're welcome.
Thanks, RMP!

@futbolista: you put in quotes, "the best league in the world," referring to the English Premier League. Can you find the link for such a (wrong) claim? It's nowhere in this article, and it's nowhere in any of my comments. So who's saying it and putting a burr under your saddle?
What the English Premier League IS, is the richest league in the world, and one with a sustainable revenue distribution system. It's been about 7 years since Portsmouth went into administration due to fiscal mismanagement in England. Meanwhile, La Liga saw a team relegated for failure to pay its players LAST YEAR.
Every year, each EPL team nets $8 million per year from the sale of the media rights to Comcast-NBCSN, for broadcast here in 'Murica alone. That's a sum that approximates what some of the La Liga minnows get in total media rights, and the American market doesn't take into account Asian rights, African rights, European rights, and the £ billion in domestic UK rights.
It accounts for the steady flow of Bundesliga players into England, and the relative parity in the league. In Germany, there are 4 teams with +10 GD or better, out of 18. In Spain, it's five out of 20. In England, the number is 8 of 20.
MOL, you've always been dazzling but you made 21 five letter words from that Spelling Bee? INCREDIBLE!!!

Never mind my post above, you beat me to it!
All the "Likes" for you. Best comment.
I eagerly await the moment when, frustrated with Hodor's lack of communication skills, Bran barks out "whatchu talkin' 'bout, Wylis?!"
What you talking about, Willis? ;-)
I enjoyed the humor of Tyrion's visit to the Dragons: "I know your Mother…..Don't eat the help!"
What you talkin' bout, Wylis?

I'm not a real analyst of the show - which is why I enjoy reading all these insights - so maybe I missed something obvious. But if Hodor's name is actually Wyllis, then what does "Hodor" mean? He had the ability to talk once and lost it in some likely traumatic experience, and now all he says is that one word. I couldn't help but wonder if it is going to be revealed as some kind of secret in plain sight. Perhaps someone else actually named Hodor is responsible for some treachery, or it's the name of a place where some such treachery took place...

Or maybe I'm reaching...
Since his mother said he was a stable boy, it could be as simple as being kicked in the head by a horse, and "Hodor" might just be "horse don't' or something equally  obvious.

I agree that the Hodor revelation was the most surprising part of this episode, followed closely by Ramsay killing his family.  I had assumed that he would go after the infant if it was a boy, but hadn't guessed that he would kill his father also.  I think most people had already figured out how Jon Snow would be resurrected.  Not much surprise there, but glad they got it over with so that storyline can move on.  At this point, I'm most intrigued by finding out why Hodor stopped speaking. That may not be what the show runners had intended.
Where is that pimp?
I would like to see Wun Wun smash Baelish.  Without Baelish the whole war would not have happened.
2 episodes in and no sign of the biggest schemer of them all, Petyr Baelish? hmmm....

So, so tired of the Ramsey subplot.  Yes, he's a psychopath; no, I do not need more evidence of this fact.  His only function seems to be torture porn and I do not see enough of his importance in any of these plot lines to justify all of his screen time.
Or Jon Snow.  It has to be a Northerner!

Watching the episode last night, I was thinking how depressing it is in the long history of feudalism, how common it was for sons to kill their fathers, brothers their brothers (Ramsey did both!) to gain power in an all-or-nothing game.

I think the fact he's around for so long is the author's (and showrunners's) commentary on that type of society. That in that type of fundamentally flawed system, it's this type of person who who end up on top. The best people could hope for most of time was Tywin (selfish but rational, never cruel for no reason). It's a rarity to have someone like Daenerys who doesn't just want a better person on the throne, but smash the overall system.

Ha! I so called it last week that Ramsay would kill off his dad! I can't wait for that psychopath to meet his end!

And I'm glad they didn't drag out Jon Snows return. I want to see what he does to the Nights Watch traitors who tried to kill him.

I'd also love to see a reunion of Sansa and Jon. The Stark family have been split up for so long. The last time they were all together was in Ep 2 of Season 1.
Thanks, RMP. The one I always enjoy is from North by Northwest. The Rear Window one is a close second.

They're not cross-country skiers, Steve?
Friend of Chuck?

Here is why I don't own Facebook stock. It is now the drug of the masses. Has been for some time. But, as always happens, something better--more enticing--will come along. maybe next month, maybe, two years from now. And when it does come, it will come with an alacrity only possible in this digital age. The race to unload its stock will be a madhouse. Not ironically, those at the later ends of the information pipeline will be the ones to sell at the greatest loss. A company that produces nothing will tank when a better nothing comes along.

Kinda ho-hum; works visually but not aurally.
And OKEMO? really? Is Stowe defunct as a skiing site?
oh well
I agree and, his the uncle's name was Uncle Martin .... very much like Uncle Martian. Good call Francis.

Here's my guess for the name "Uncle Martian:" It's a tribute to "My Favorite Martian", the classic 60's sitcom starring Bill Bixby as "Tim O'Hara" and Ray Walston, who played his "Uncle Martin." We'll know for sure if the characters in their commercials have TV antennas come out of their heads.

Quite common.

Often plants will produce an overrun, and sell of the remainder as "gray market." Basically, I issue you a PO for 1000 units, and you produce 2000. 1k goes to me and 1k goes out the back door. This is how authentic merchandise can often make it's way into the gray market.

We recently were looking to source new plants for apparel goods. 7/10 were already producing counterfeit merch when we did our surprise audits.

Not kidding...

Yes, and it is reasonable that Theon might get confused as to which it was by only hearing barking sounds. Clearly they held off on the more vicious dogs because Ramsey still needs Sansa and an heir to cement his claim to the North, but in the fear of the moment it is not unreasonable to understand that Theon might think the worst of Ramsey.
The hungry dogs were huge, some sort of Mastiff.

I thought it was fairly obvious that the hounds who slaughtered Walda and her baby were different dogs than those who tracked Sansa & Theon. The killer dogs had short, upright ears, possibly cropped ears. The tracking dogs were Bloodhounds with long, droopy ears.

Pretty good episode; good to see Jon return.
Totally disagree.  Snow can and should stay at the Wall to fight off the White Walkers and their zombie army.  I mean, who else would the Wildings and Watch accept as the leader of both?

Also, couldn't he say his service at the wall is done. I thought it was to the death. Well, he died. So I think he can walk away from the wall without worrying about a broken promise.

Also, does his resurrection leave him invulnerable to the ice king or more vulnerable.... hmmmmm
I disagree. She seemed genuinely surprised that her predictions did not come true.

The pacing seemed slow - this could be because the Bran story is so spacey.  We missed an update on Danerys. Melisandre is not actually a fraud - we know that she created a shadow demon who killed Renly in front of Brienne, we know that she has shapeshifter qualities herself (old lady? not?) - what she said in this episode was that all her predictions for Stannis - huge victory in battle, taking the Iron Throne - were lies, but not that she was unaware of the lies. She does seem to be working on behalf of the true heir to the Iron throne, hence her work to rid the world of Renly and Stannis and Stannis' daughter. We can only wonder at what she will do the House of Lannister. Having revived Jon Snow - as we always knew she would - we can surmise that he is vital to her plan, but who is he really? As for Snow - there are parallels to Christianity, in that the persecuted leader put to death for doing good for many has now been resurrected. If the plot follows that parallel, then Snow cannot stay at the Wall - like the prophet, the resurrected are not accepted at home - he will have to leave the Wall. Home - the title of the episode - turned up a lot - destruction of family members at the Boltons' and the Greyjoys' just as Ramsay turns for home, the Lannisters' plots to save home from the Sparrows. Best line: Tyrion: "I drink and I know things."
Well, if Ramsay tries a sneak attack at night on Castle Black, he'd be in for the surprise of his life.  I hope he get smote by the giant.

Actually I called Ghost the Chekhov gun over the mantelpiece while watching last night; as long as he is around something is going to continue the Jon Snow biz... the camera focus on the direwolf ("six hundred pounds of sin," more or less) during the runup to the gasping resurrection was a giveaway.
The real giveaway was Kit Harrinton's name appearing prominently in the opening credits.

I half-expected the Jon Snow reanimation - leaving him in full view for so long on a slab suggested that, in GOT, he was the gun in the Chekhov's Gun writing metaphor. Chekhov would approve Snow's reanimation as structurally necessary.

Ramsay's killing Roose surprised me - but not what Ramsay did next to his step-mother or brother. That seemed inevitable after he murdered his father. It also looks like Ramsay's destined to meet his end at the Wall, since it appears he's predicting he will have only the Watch to defeat, not the Watch plus, oh, a hundred thousand Wildlings.

Also, once Tyrion went down to visit the dragons, I knew he'd free them and survive. Dinlkage's centrality in the evolving story dictates that hee won't be meeting his end anytime soon.

As for Jaime and Cersei and the Red Keep Lannisters, I predict the lot of them will be spending several episodes - to no successful end - rearranging their deck chairs on the Titanic/Iron Throne. I suspect all that feng shui in the Keep won't save them.

Onward...!
he was told over and over, Kill the boy.  He is AA and will wield the true Lightbringer.
Coffee.  Spat.
Best comment. Well done.

If Beric Dondarrion's experiences of coming back from the deaths is any guide, Jon Snow will have long term memory losses.  According to Ygritte's logic then, Jon Snow will come back knowing less than nothing?

So I believe that every God mentioned in the show is depicted by a character.
The Father = The High Sparrow
The Mother = The Mother of Dragons(obviously)
The Maiden = Sansa
The Warrior = Jon Snow
The Smith = Petyr Baelish or Tyrion Lannister
The Crone = Melissadre
The Stranger = Jaquen Hagar
The Drown God = Euron Greyjoy
The Old Gods = Bran Stark/ Three Eyed Raven
The Many Faced God = Ayra Stark
